item.title: 145 – Altar
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Altar simply a flat place second horizon line rising stone from swirl stable table rock mid-river paled green moss fuzz grooves channeling a thousand bloodlines lost & found set down laid out of a Sunday over churning wrack & plunge … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Altar

simply a flat
place

second horizon
line

rising stone
from swirl

stable table
rock

mid-river
paled green

moss fuzz
grooves

channeling
a thousand bloodlines

lost & found
set down

laid out
of a Sunday

over churning wrack
& plunge

prostrate before
the Lord

descends
a cloud

gentle spray
settled over

the face
a cool veil

knit
& simply rent

in the simple act
of breathing

item.title: 143 – Marrow
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Marrow Twelve turkey vultures keened and circled their spiral staircase slow eyes on the dog hunting with us the dead wood and snags along the bank in this empty land of rim rock and closed oases, hidden but for their … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Marrow

Twelve turkey vultures keened
and circled their spiral
staircase slow eyes on the dog
hunting with us the dead
wood and snags along the bank
in this empty land of rim
rock and closed oases, hidden
but for their eyes.
The bone I packed in
on my hip, deer joint
pried loose last fall in autumn’s
pale glow. Gleaming Bowie blade.
Flesh weighted, packed up, hauled out
in shifts, a last remnant for the dog to gnaw. I thought
of them at the fire, the twelve,
and their fine feathers
we found, gathered in light
handfuls, burned as tinder.
Each brittle hollow filled
with guttering blue heat
held in place a moment longer
before leafing fully into flame
sending sparks out up
into the emptiness above.

item.title: 144 – Water
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Water We boil down to so little: salt, trace elements calcified in the soil. Dust to dust. Rehydrate to animate. We are more than crystalline. We live as skinned sponges. Wrung out we pale; bloated we sop. We require current … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Water

We boil down to so little:
salt, trace elements
calcified in the soil.
Dust to dust.

Rehydrate
to animate.

We are more
than crystalline.

We live as skinned
sponges. Wrung out
we pale; bloated
we sop.

We require current
to remain

lest we wither
like a creek gone gluch.

Hips and elbows,
sharp teeth, sharp tongues
tent the sail
of the body.

Fear coats the mouth
in dust.

Water water everywhere
but nary a drop.

The sustaining wave
washed out: acres of sand,
white shells glittering,
our own glossy reflection

a pillar
of salt.

item.title: 142 – Onionskin
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Onionskin At last they are laid down peeled apart translucent skins to be written on that once held back a wave of viscera cascading now holds words pressed against one another ink does not bleed every page remains its own … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Onionskin

At last they are laid down

peeled apart translucent

skins to be written on

that once held back

a wave of viscera cascading

now holds words

pressed against one another

ink does not bleed

every page remains

its own

amidst the sheaf

 

(d)

item.title: 141 – Celery
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Celery He must have asked thirty people for fifty cents to help him look toward the future though he couldn’t see straight. I watched him make his way towards me, ignored or waved off by everyone else. Shuffle step. Lumber. … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Celery

He must have asked thirty people
for fifty cents to help him
look toward the future
though he couldn’t see straight.
I watched him make his way
towards me, ignored or waved off
by everyone else.
Shuffle step. Lumber. Beard.
Bleary eyed. Retarded? Drunk?
Hard to tell until he was there
in front of me, asking.
I gave him what I had,
which wasn’t much
besides eye contact
and a bag of celery.
He took it, munching
as he made his rounds.
He drifted off eventually
a little more full of the essential
vitamins and minerals,
a little more prepared
to face the life he’s in.

item.title: 140 – Spectrum
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Spectrum The neighborhood’s alight tonight with Bird’s singing: shout gerbil gerbil! from the backyard. Down the way the corgis lose their minds. He’s just playing, girls. Bird’s got ribbons on his legs that fly when he runs, little flags like … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Spectrum

The neighborhood’s alight tonight
with Bird’s singing: shout gerbil
gerbil! from the backyard.
Down the way the corgis
lose their minds. He’s just playing, girls.
Bird’s got ribbons on his legs
that fly when he runs, little flags
like he’s a country making
and remaking borders.
If you see him in line at the store
he stands stiff, eyes pinched shut
with the help of his fingers
and rocks, recites numbers.
Don’t stare. Smile and pass
right on by. He’ll feel you.
He’s a pirate-dinosaur.
Just the other day I found him
on the bridge at the creek
peering at himself peering
at himself. Like he was reading
water or the mind
of the giant pond Koi
that’s just an orange road cone.
He falls into a pit that is him
but can’t know the edges of.
Bangarang! Bangarang, Bird.
If you cup your hands
to your ear you’ll catch more
of what he’s got to give.

item.title: 139 – Solidarity
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Solidarity I took a cue from the cat and the beer I drank in the sun in the chair I shared with said cat and settled down to doze, head in hand. But my body rebelled at each subtle dip … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Solidarity

I took a cue
from the cat
and the beer I drank
in the sun
in the chair
I shared with said cat
and settled down
to doze, head in hand.
But
my body rebelled
at each subtle dip
to viscerally kick me
AWAKE!
I’ve read that pulse
is my body’s last
ditch effort
to keep me alive
for my body thinks
of sleep as death.
I like that
my body watches
out for me,
thinking existential
thoughts, even when
I’m not. Needless
to say I didn’t nap,
and in solidarity
nudged the cat
out of my lap
so we could see
what we’d been missing.

item.title: 138 – Sunday
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Sunday Cobwebbed brown bottle filled with a spray of paper flowers and the early light I’m struck by. The insistence of sin again and again. Dead. Alive. Dead. I can’t untangle the inexorable down to its individual threads, finer than … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Sunday

Cobwebbed brown bottle
filled with a spray of paper
flowers and the early light
I’m struck by. The insistence
of sin again and again. Dead.
Alive. Dead. I can’t untangle
the inexorable down
to its individual threads, finer
than spider’s silk, than a cat-hair
shadow left in my lap.
My mind distends, bells
out beyond reason into the fog
of faith where everything is creak
and gray. I wait there
until you come to settle
at my side. None clearer
but now, not alone.

item.title: 137 – Fargo
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Fargo The neighbors are chipping their rhododendron hedge. I can’t help but think of the end to Fargo. His lonely foot jiggling in the teeth. Dull winter snow petaled red. The house, the empty lake beyond. Isn’t that how it … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Fargo

The neighbors
are chipping
their rhododendron hedge.

I can’t help
but think of the end
to Fargo.

His lonely foot
jiggling
in the teeth.

Dull winter
snow
petaled red.

The house,
the empty lake
beyond.

Isn’t that how it is?

Iced over
by the odd
memory flickering.

A scene
forgotten for years
returns.

I bend
to tie my shoe
and lose

myself
in the shadow
I make.

item.title: 136 – Reunion
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Reunion Bone cancer. His bum luck. Never baptized but by rain water and bitters. Cigar smoke, expensive lavender soap, a weakness for pistachio ice cream. The IV drips a rhythm they learn to count down when he can’t speak. Pain. … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Reunion

Bone cancer. His bum luck.
Never baptized but by rain water
and bitters. Cigar smoke, expensive
lavender soap, a weakness
for pistachio ice cream.

The IV drips a rhythm they learn
to count down when he can’t
speak. Pain. Pain. Pain.
Rest. A pasteled garden
of nurses–Summer, Rose, Daphne–
tends his vitals.

Hannity gives way to Maddow
on the sly. Indians home stand.
The Weather Channel, swirling
announcements of flooding
down south. Phone calls made
and relayed. It’s okay, Pop.

Distant family loiters
in the halls. His dying
they take with them
to the hotel, smell it
on their hands.

Drinks while the kids swim.
They take the shape of the sunken
poolside chairs. Stories surface
like stones. One by one
taken into their mouths.
His godawful temper. His love

of the foxtrot and fine wine.
The time he ruined the Buick.
His elegant racism. His work ethic.
The dog shampoo incident.
How all their fingers crook the same.
They laugh and it sounds
as if he’s there.

The kids swim on.

There’s nothing to be done.
House packed and boxed,
papers filed, arrangements made.
Waiting in shifts fills every day
to the brim.

Ice chips. Blue sponges.
O2 stats. Wilting flowers
in a plastic vase.
The eroding terrain
of his heartbeat.

When he goes it’s quiet.
Early. Still. Most asleep
or pacing just outside.
They never heard him
slip away, passing
with a wink and nod.

At the hotel they rise
again. Instant coffee
in paper cups. Old
underwear in the sink.
TVs in their block of rooms
loud with morning
cartoons.
